C0C1A318598B46ADB78E7439BCCB850F.description: Co-construct a tool (e.g., rubric, checklist, self-evaluation form or peer-evaluation form) and use it to assess the process and products involved in their student-directed study.

4DCBFE00B3C34F1898595B301121262C.description: Share the results of student-directed research through a platform of one’s choosing (e.g., research paper, display, presentation, performance, demonstration, infomercial, video).

6F3A4FA060184762AC48D263C40C9BCD.description: Assemble and reflect on a portfolio that demonstrates an understanding of a career choice related to law with information that could include: initial and continuing educational requirements; duties and skills required for this occupation; the work environment, including typical hours worked and locations; current wages received in Saskatchewan; physical, mental and emotional stresses related to this occupation; workplace hazards and safety considerations; other professionals with whom they interact; professional and/or licensing requirements in Canada and Saskatchewan; future trends impacting the occupation; reflection upon personal suitability for a specific law related occupation; employment opportunities with a law degree, other than a traditional law practice; and employment opportunities in the legal profession without a law degree.

FC2BC139A6FC47DA9C82F41B8E711DE6.description: Defend or refute a position based on an analysis of a collection of relevant cases.

7DB44FF0CFA84C5EB76659DE839EE5B5.description: Design a multi-perspective investigation related to a topic of study in Law 30 that includes a position statement, a counter position, evidence from multiple sources and a conclusion.

84076F7A2993487DB5D798EFB47EB706.description: Design and carry out a detailed exploration of one or more topics of personal interest relevant to Law 30.

829A3F03E5EB4B96A84CF54FC1E0473A.description: Assess the role of media in the Canadian justice system.

CCA0ED73CC0F489397F521FB1AC480E1.description: Interview people who work in legal professions to increase understanding of a contemporary legal topic.

537E2280AD8A46B983E9D555C06F0DE5.description: Evaluate the effects of globalization on the creation and application of laws to Canadians considering factors such as: application of Canadian laws abroad; similarity of Canadian laws to laws in other places; extradition requirements and processes; and, political immunity.

341E63B7A5AA41AA811D64255D360711.description: Examine the challenges that diverse worldviews present when interpreting and applying laws in an increasingly multicultural society.

F377B1E414DA429987C2F5C023DCC0D3.description: Develop a policy to address a local contemporary legal issue.

3657CC2C41CD4D7CA08CF03E4C8299DE.description: Predict how issues related to emerging technologies challenge current legal thinking and administration of justice in Canada.

E4B5F1F9B96B4DCD933098FE88131289.description: Explore Indigenous justice issues in contemporary Canadian society.

B7233CAEE96C4C198BA45398A60C067A.description: Hypothesize how the legal recognition of Indigenous sovereignty might impact the relationship of Indigenous peoples with the Canadian government.

E57DCF3E81214052B9E97F2B3D356D63.description: Examine programs available to help people come to Canada such as travel, study, work and immigration (e.g., citizenship, permanent resident, refugee protection).

A19FE1BD88C54801B501387AA541D73D.description: Describe the legal implications of various international and domestic political events, humanitarian crises and environmental issues.

717515C4971649AE8BAD81C429BF1F05.description: Analyze international legal issues that affect or have affected Canada including participation in various United Nations conventions.

63D59A57A4FF4BC28029E0F045647BA3.description: Discuss the implications of federal policy on the provinces and issues surrounding competing provincial interests in federalism.

4194E9F4F92F4D2DAEFCD57E84F5D713.description: Examine challenges related to access to justice and identify programs (e.g., legal aid) designated to help remedy the issue.

3E04A54A545146D89D025AF44A8E1246.description: Investigate contemporary legal issues that affect Canadians.

EC2EFB99720C4AABB437BCD3F1085270.description: Discuss the limits on freedom of expression when using social media.

C49D7C54B7B242B380238F3160C60381.description: Identify and justify the age of consent for different legal circumstances such as contracts, sexual consent, medical consent, tattoos, piercings, use of social media and online spaces.

4ECBE35C51EE467C9E8B116CF1B3D8D2.description: Compare public perception versus patterns and statistics over time regarding youth crime.

18CAA441C0994DAEBC3F9591BFFF89FF.description: Examine scenarios where youth could be charged and sentenced as an adult in Canadian law.

36DC4D615C694E30B50659DEAC17E098.description: Examine how youth are treated differently than adults in the criminal justice system during arrest, detention, trial, sentencing and incarceration.

8B9B968B81C64FB5A339CD38BDFA1F82.description: Explain the legal rights of youth with respect to: wishes regarding parenting arrangements; protection from physical abuse, emotional abuse, sexual abuse and neglect; and, right to sue for damages.

1770E812C5574DDAAF160DADA3B6307B.description: Describe current Saskatchewan laws that are designed to protect the rights of youth and to regulate their behaviour such as: the Child and Family Services Act (1989-90); the Advocate for Children and Youth Act (2012); the Education Act (1995); and, The Saskatchewan Employment Act (2013).

4B669F0D12BB4E1FB0EBEA74F286812E.description: Debate the rationale for treating youth differently from adults with respect to issues such as: voting age; driving; age of consent; school attendance; contracts; criminality; medical treatment with or without parental consent; and, consumption and purchasing controlled substances.

643BA2734FB14069985A2F7320BA7BB7.description: Explore how brain maturity can have an impact on youths’ criminal behaviour.

7898977BF0C34F7A955FA1D0FCD35732.description: Discuss systemic factors that may lead to youth criminality (e.g., addictions, trauma, poverty, gangs, violence).

6A61714D48304A479AE42E00425E69D6.description: Examine the rights youth are provided under the Youth Criminal Justice Act (2003).

34F5BBB1861A45C0BEC0328ECD2C2675.description: Explore changes in Canadian legislation regarding youth such as the Juvenile Delinquents Act (1984), the Young Offenders Act (1984), the Youth Criminal Justice Act (2003) regarding youth, including the legal definition of youth.

51D1A0EB19944F0DB2EF3B1B52BFF550.description: Analyze the fundamental rights described in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child (1989) and the guiding principles of the Youth Criminal Justice Act (2003).

D1906340F5E846E3ACD6788A0E2359EF.description: Examine how and why youth are treated differently than adults in Canadian law.

2C6AF0D091144D2EBEA220A5AF779351.description: Examine employment standards and workplace rights and responsibilities in The Saskatchewan Employment Act (2013) such as: occupational health and safety; wage and pay; work schedules; vacations, public holidays, leave and absences; employment standards in professions and industries; human rights (e.g., harassment, pay equity); and, regulation regarding notice of termination or dismissal.

82A7E5D828B84FE3931E82C36A6CA852.description: Recognize that a legal document from one jurisdiction may not be valid in another.

FFCB22D69017405498CAC37401075955.description: Identify possible dangers of relying on non-professional legal advice.

F72409A09D904D7385AE42EE96A0FE23.description: Assess instances when an individual should consult a lawyer for legal services related to civil law.

565E93A1FD214BA2BB1B901CE9DF255E.description: Examine remedies available to both parties in situations where a contract has been breached.

3544B3115B70477EB334E4146018F9DE.description: Discuss the Consumer Protection Act (2013) and critique common consumer contracts to determine whose interests are being protected in the contract.

9CB38CFB7E5B4FE5818EB3D6C5A1FE3C.description: Create scenarios that include the required elements (e.g., offer, acceptance, consideration) and potential invalidating factors (e.g., consent, capacity, duress, undue influence, mistake, misrepresentation, illegal contract, contrary to public policy) of a valid contract.

1EC5E4D61C474E7CBA06A8399B4B5D44.description: Explore the characteristics and purpose of non-contractual legal documents (e.g., wills, power of attorney and health care directives) and the legislative alternatives when these are not in place or deemed invalid.

B1DEEC2331104D6496D967B577F4859B.description: Analyze different situations (e.g., landlord-tenant agreements, terms of service agreements, warranties, mortgages, loans, online agreements) where legal contracts exist.

0F31D4C9960A46E8AF9D804713C41AB6.description: Explore how civil laws regulate the daily lives of Canadians.

864E89B6769341369C5D304B0034F898.description: Analyze how family law affects families with differing societal values, cultural expectations and economic circumstances.

EAB3CC8B9BC64ECF969A1CD03E1D4473.description: Differentiate between past and present government policies and traditional Indigenous practices related to interventions into Indigenous families, such as adoption of Indigenous children, Sixties Scoop, residential schools, Jordan’s Principle and interactions with government agencies and programs.

BC7C1417D89B4CC1B4B4BB958C9B2FFB.description: Describe the rights and responsibilities of parents and guardians and how family law protects the rights of children, including topics such as: considerations of the best interests of the child; safety, parenting arrangements; adoption; and, the role of government agencies and programs.

E887B12368D046A3B04D490339E82FED.description: Examine the grounds for and legal implications of, separation, divorce and annulment.

6EB8C5185F824BC29F7EBB630B0C30E2.description: Assess the benefits and disadvantages of court orders, voluntary agreements or mediated settlements in the termination of family relationships.

6E61A5D835DB46C4A7C58B90C7577701.description: Evaluate the different contracts or agreements (e.g., cohabitation agreements, the division of family property, parenting arrangements, child and spousal support) that parties can enter into before, during or after a marriage or cohabitation relationship.

6417376A4146425998B9384AD7A2F516.description: Assess the complex interplay between cultural and/or religious customs, marriage laws and the Charter in terms of the legal status of a relationship (e.g., polygamy, polyamory, arranged marriages, marriage outside Canada).

21D8009C5B404B31BAA62D9B13130DDD.description: Examine how the definitions of family, marriage and cohabitation have evolved and continue to evolve through legislation and court decisions.

B902B11017904EAA8E17E624D693BE37.description: Analyze case studies to identify common legal requirements of a marriage (e.g., age, mental capacity, marital status, consanguinity) and common-law relationships in Saskatchewan and in other provinces of Canada.

F9448F992E914222A5A975C8DB535EE4.description: Investigate the legal implications that result from forming, changing and terminating various types of family relationships.

773316DD7F23420E87673F99BCCE71B1.description: Investigate the purposes and the processes involving in conducting public inquiries in a variety of cases (e.g., The National Inquiry into MMIWG) including: The role of the Inquiries Act (2005); how an inquiry is initiated; how it functions; the roles and the responsibilities of the participants; the impact of the conclusions and recommendations made as a result; and, the limitations and challenges of the process.

A9280D04CF2F4BC4B630D6DCD94B233A.description: Assess alternate dispute resolution processes (e.g., negotiation, mediation, arbitration, tribunals) available to settle civil disputes.

318A5D56887A49A2A71B20E9FC2882B6.description: Plan and present a small claims court case using provincial templates and guidelines.

D0D95919458946AAA14F41DD122AE6B2.description: Justify the types of remedies and damages the court may order given a specific scenario.

C5C624D9A8DB45F888F2C11A85F05A52.description: Investigate the purpose, benefits and challenges of participating in class action lawsuits and describe situations where they might be appropriate.

D519B37EBEF94633A4D818C10381D88D.description: Describe the remedies (e.g., punitive damages, special damages, general damages, injunctions) available under tort law and identify methods of enforcing civil judgments.

6DB17FBE9BEC4519945BA84B9DC069E8.description: Analyze intentional and unintentional tort cases while considering the possible defences.

2716291E11714C79AB45E7F61051133A.description: Generate a list of circumstances when one might consider instigating a civil action and identify barriers to commencing a civil action (e.g., costs, access).

1496B52C54FA4FDE828698760B2A6487.description: Classify civil law cases as tort, contract, family, employment, wills and estates or property law.

A588F0C69F724D228AF8E6DA6D700B11.description: Identify levels of courts within civil law, including small claims court.

97B5F3DEC6094A0E8190290549EB7523.description: Differentiate Canadian civil law from Canadian criminal law, considering factors such as purpose, role and levels of the courts, procedures, outcomes, enforcement of sanctions, availability of legal aid, onus and burden of proof.

F4F8C82BF66E47948C98C5A79E3C259E.description: Examine the elements and processes of dispute resolution in Canadian civil law.

B12F8C6C161B4C03963E2DACBDBC7514.description: Examine the impacts of the interrelationship between law enforcement agencies and communities.

FCA0CF34CDC840A5ACD5BDC217C7E70E.description: Analyse government responses in light of wrongful imprisonment and other miscarriages of justice and justify appropriateness of response in given situations.

7ECEADD1B83C4089AF873D3D4265121F.description: Examine ways to assess levels of recidivism and impact of integrating back high risk offenders in the community.

BD38A076A78A44ADAAD40D266065657B.description: Explore supports available for offenders integrating back to the community.

AFB85AAC70884F62972450026083480C.description: Compare public perception versus patterns and statistics regarding sentencing and corrections.

AC426DD8DC0849D8B52776C35B955ABB.description: Examine systemic barriers (e.g., racial profiling, court wait times, cost and availability of legal resources) in the Canadian criminal justice system.

CEDFEAB81F5343F9986A3A442AFFC29E.description: Critique how the Canadian justice system responds to people in challenging circumstances (e.g., poverty, mental health issues, language and cultural barriers, victims of trauma).

084114E7E5CB414381D18977BE937EC0.description: Explore the impact of crime on the community (e.g., victims and their families, offender after serving sentence, family of the offender, workplaces).

61DB1E4D40A74AE8AE9BA8406461951C.description: Analyze interactions between participants in the Canadian justice system and the community.

C0CAA4FC58AA44A3A956E2B1C3C48281.description: Explore the impact of the Jordan decision (2016) as a measure to improve the effectiveness of the Canadian justice system.

F962A819C3BC4412B30486AABAB7C768.description: Analyze the purpose, impact and validity of crime statistics.

633FBEDE3A5346EDA1640A027E66F70A.description: Examine the effectiveness of various correctional models (e.g., custody, maximum-security, minimum-security) and programs (e.g., substance abuse intervention, sex offender treatment, literacy development, work experience, treatment courts).

3AE6720DBC674DAC9FC888B71AC55C5A.description: Justify the appropriate use and effectiveness of plea bargaining in the criminal justice system.

632575364F1D4E7D82B2AFE42E5658C3.description: Investigate the purpose, process, limitations and importance of Gladue factors on the determination of a sentence.

B7DEB4A9CBD04C3994E1070BC3B0D2E7.description: Examine factors that contribute to the over-representation of Indigenous people in the justice system.

327DC4E5E1174A03BEBC6F973CC38B1F.description: Debate if imprisonment is an effective way to change long term human behavior

FBA33F3E688D494D8A710290F41939F6.description: Explore how rehabilitation, reparation, sense of responsibility and acknowledgement of harm done to victims and communities are reflected in the goals of restorative justice.

403312ACF52B4ADA998C6786E8F30700.description: Identify the various sentences (e.g., discharges, suspended sentences, conditional sentence orders, incarceration, electronic monitoring, community service hours) possible within the Canadian justice system and evaluate the appropriateness of a sentence given a particular case.

6A8AFE937BF944928191E24B9AB03B84.description: Discuss alternatives (e.g., parole, probation) to incarceration available to convicted offenders in relation to rehabilitation.

95E0D040B7CB4E5283A32527E35DC79C.description: Describe the various goals (e.g., rehabilitation, reparation, sense of responsibility, acknowledgement of harm done, deterrence) of sentencing and justify appropriateness in given situations.

0B6EC837C03848449DB9208AF751D19F.description: Discuss how certain actions are criminalized or decriminalized using a variety of cultural perspectives.

5819B09E66614237AD46B8BAA29CCB4D.description: Assess how shifting worldviews have contributed to changes in understanding of right and wrong and the effects on legal systems/criminal justice.

447B585C8AC246E29EB88CDD97706DD7.description: Explore possible root causes of crime (e.g., addictions, violence, abuse, trauma, poverty, gangs).

CA4D10B7A45C48FAB31A01B871611159.description: Critique the impact and effectiveness of the Canadian justice system.

7D34F0A4E38D428AA78A66A281B8683F.description: Differentiate between federal penitentiaries and provincial correctional facilities, including various levels of security within, length of sentence and programs available (e.g., substance abuse intervention, sex offender treatment, literacy development, work experience, treatment courts).

DA0219F130444C0FB62CB4B0DA6DA0B1.description: Model the process (e.g., investigation, arrest, voir dire, trial, sentencing, appeals) of a criminal procedure.

A0BAAB50A5654BD39AE224CA537907E8.description: Examine the purpose and use of processes available in the Canadian justice system, including presentence reports, victim impact statements and restorative practices.

24DD13E5BCF842C58C3AB8E106AA5A03.description: Identify factors to ensure the judicial process is fair to the accused (e.g., presumption of innocence, right to jury, trial of peers).

1491ECD737F2436C8839E8CD27BE3E91.description: Investigate the various defences (e.g., threshold test, air of reality test and reasonable doubt) available to defend against criminal charges and evaluate the applicability of a defence given a particular case.

A9FF112680D64126A9985A011D7E2DA3.description: Identify the mens rea vs. actus reus in a variety of case law.

D7C6F296C775480880C4826591170BB5.description: Assess the different levels of policing (e.g., municipal, RCMP, Indigenous police services, conservation officers and highway patrol officers, sheriff department) available in Saskatchewan communities and justify the roles, responsibilities and limitations of powers.

C3BEA08C55A44D82A7FF200F1BE72A91.description: Analyze the roles and responsibilities of institutions (e.g., police, courts, judiciary, correctional system, legal and paralegal professionals, victim services, community-based justice organizations) within the criminal justice system.

507CBB3C028C457FAA93D6DBD8ABCE95.description: Outline the different types of court jurisdictions in Canada and describe the anticipated progress of a criminal procedure through the Canadian courts.

93D8C57D18994760A42B10C46E95CA0D.description: Compare the types of offences (e.g., indictable, summary and hybrid) in the Criminal Code of Canada (1985) and identify in a variety of cases.

FE6B91F7BF0A4982B1AC4C42C535CBF8.description: Discuss what constitutes a crime according to the Criminal Code of Canada (1985).

6D4939EBFEC14D4F99E6C5CDF11F63CF.description: Differentiate between elements of criminal law and civil law such as purpose, role of the courts, procedures, outcomes, enforcement of sanctions, onus and burden of proof.

B4DF8E646B0C484A9D2A281A21B37A8B.description: Investigate the elements and processes of Canadian criminal law.

AC33C833371F4E0B91A29C5EEBA69BBD.description: Explore the steps one might take if they believe their Charter rights have been violated.

84BDF207E24848F0AFB96527A16BF212.description: Examine how groups or individuals (e.g., Indigenous people, treaty rights holder, gender and/or sexually diverse, minority languages) struggle to have their rights recognized and protected.

A5297D72ADB84CAF9CACBDE9B567942E.description: Assess scenarios and case studies that illustrate how courts interpret laws in light of the Charter to shape and inform current laws.

2BF90B8240D54C2FA00BAC327691DFFB.description: Examine processes and supports available to offer protection against breaches of rights and freedoms such as: the Canadian Human Rights Act (1985); the Saskatchewan Human Rights Code; the Saskatchewan Human Rights Commission; the Ombudsman Saskatchewan Office; the Saskatchewan Children and Youth Advocate; the Official Language Commissioner; and, the Office of the Treaty Commissioner.

ED1F66F49C0C4D889A89E251C0949067.description: Justify how the Constitution and the Charter's protect existing rights, inherent Indigenous rights and minority language educational rights.

8E03688497B94C16B85E62DE611E1DC1.description: Explain why the “reasonable limits clause” and the “notwithstanding clause” exist and justify situations when they can be applied.

8BE97A06FE324639A7255D481036CC85.description: Discuss the limits of the Charter's jurisdiction as it only applies to the relationship between the state and the citizens.

F6052E86A882475BB5288338B79B7DDA.description: Examine the structure and content of the Charter, including its jurisdiction, its enforcement, how it can be amended and the difference between Charter rights and Charter freedoms.

E7358166A95F4491840B8A23D738AB97.description: Evaluate how the Charter attempts to seek balance between the rights of the individual versus those of society and apply to specific scenarios and case studies.

E1ED02450D3943EE92C1457B7C5D05FA.description: Investigate the historical context for the inclusion of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms (Charter) (1982) in the Constitution Act (Constitution) (1982).

91161202682646C79D0430094F12E732.description: Assess the importance of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

82C53BD9FF6649B4A6D58AE0DA079B5A.description: Explore the origins of Saskatchewan's Language Act and examine the impact of this legislation on the work of the provincial legislature.

C76781279D5D4A99A37B5DB9C16279D9.description: Create a plan that includes strategies to affect changes to current laws in Canada at the local, provincial and federal levels.

5D7AAB5095154F128FDB18E142322539.description: Predict possible changes to Canadian laws regarding emerging issues and support these predictions.

3B68C6BFD2B94EC395FEC288A58C46A2.description: Investigate the motivation and impact of individuals or organizations who have influenced the evolution of law in Canada.

4FC1B1EAFC43406DA028F5322CEE270B.description: Explain various provisions in Canadian law (e.g., Articles 2, 23, 29, 33 in the Charter) that may be used to accommodate the diverse interests and needs of individuals and groups.

FFCC76DEB06B4E6FAB17EA460D20CA43.description: Discuss how differing cultural understandings of treaties between the Crown and First Nations peoples lead to ongoing negotiation and dialogue to resolve outstanding issues.

412AB12067624C98AF55742E8B03BBDD.description: Examine promises made in treaties and legal cases related to treaty land entitlement claims in Canada.

BEE16C81D55D482CA351508113C747C3.description: Investigate the evolving legal relationship between First Nations, Métis and Inuit peoples and non-Indigenous Canadians, including treaty relationships and truth and reconciliation.

1EBBEB1C29AD4DD1A8A704A0CE33AA53.description: Explore the diversity of First Nations, Métis and Inuit traditional restorative practices (e.g., talking circle, humour and shaming for minor offences, banishment for serious offences and value restoration over punishment).

0B9B35A484684F448A4D6E03BDCC2FC9.description: Examine how the idea of cooperative federalism works in relation to legislation, regulation, funding and administration.

E781A4B1C47440DD8B63280E284FC0F5.description: Compare the law-making roles and powers typically associated with the executive, legislative and judicial branches of provincial and/or federal governments.

7B2FFB1562E24C4580147152790E5C51.description: Summarize the process of how new laws are created in Canada at the local, provincial and federal levels.

A205DC8A0F7549C79F34C57A5E327945.description: Examine factors that can influence the creation of new laws in Canada as a result of shifting societal and cultural values and advances in technology such as: the Slavery Abolition Act (1833); the right to vote; the abolition of the death penalty (1976); the Canada Health Act (1984); the Canadian Human Rights Act (1985); the Assisted Dying Law (2016); the Assisted Human Reproduction Act (2004); the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act (1996); the decriminalization of abortion; digital citizenship; politics and social movements; and climate change.

715A6EFC60804894A8B7CC9AA0BFC226.description: Discuss how diverse worldviews can influence the creation of, or change, a law.

20706B08B02648E484360A1F35CA9C39.description: Analyze how and why laws change over time.

5E4D5BBF82EF4DD3A07A8AE2EFEFF308.description: Examine the role of judges in the Canadian judicial system.

10BAD570AD5144B5BC3B4EFAD05DD045.description: Examine safeguards (e.g., impartial and independent judiciary, jury of one’s peers, right to counsel, presumption of innocence, courts of equity, right to appeal) in law that should protect Canadians from abuse of power by the state and ensure fairness.

0E11581AD8084F28ACABE20347ABDFA4.description: Debate criteria for just laws and systems of justice and apply to scenarios and case studies.

3D39D443F1B54B279642E5260D0C434D.description: Compare the purposes and functions of law and the justice system in Canadian society today with traditional Indigenous approaches to law and justice (e.g., restorative vs. punitive justice).

B16FF765A68E44189181A1A5BA7FD219.description: Examine how the historical roots of law in Canada stem from Indigenous legal systems, British common law and the Civil Code of Québec (1991).

20B090087E384E05B041C498B6967E07.description: Investigate elements that influence Canada’s legal system such as: the Constitution Act (Constitution) (1982) including The Charter of Rights and Freedoms; the idea of cooperative federalism such as the division of powers and jurisdictional responsibilities between the federal government, the provinces and the territories; treaties (e.g., the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child [1989], the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples [UNDRIP] [2007], the numbered treaties in Canada [1871-1921]); the Indian Act (1876); Canadian case law; and, worldviews (e.g., beliefs, customs, philosophy, religion).

E0DE6B78C2DB437FBF048FB505C91F28.description: Examine the difference between equality and equity as they relate to the concepts of justice and the application of laws.

7A7862231DBA4380A76A88253E5D8D5E.description: Identify examples of ways in which law is a part of everyday life in Canada.

62F09FFF4D4A45A1A8F1075D638FB57E.description: Explain why the rule of law is a fundamental principle in democratic societies and relate it to examples in Canadian society.

C98DFB70F9A343EF80175988A15F5B14.description: Predict the consequences of a society without laws.

11DA45C2A980465284905A765D4BA4F2.description: Debate whether the primary function of law is to create order or provide freedoms for members of its society.

50E86E2307734F32993C4818F74413CC.description: Identify the influence of societal worldviews on the organization of historical and contemporary legal systems (e.g., Indigenous legal systems, Sharia law, Mosaic law, Hammurabi’s law code, Law of the Prairie).

96F7EA7BC6BD48ED897BB1FE589C8F16.description: Evaluate the purpose and function of law in societies.
